title: UP! Modified Extruder Feeder *No Moving Parts* V2

description.text: A re-designed UP! Extruder Feeder/Cable Tray design. Removing the roller bearing and housing and replacing with spring steel guide element. This gives greater flexibility in filament thickness diameter, along with the added simplicity of design. Includes a fitting for air line supply to cool the extruder gear.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
UPDATE 03/08/2012 Version 2 has been released with fittings for two 50mm fans (to suit heatsinks) and adjusted filament outlet and air line positions to minimise mis-feeds. New files below, and am keeping the originals for those who don't want to add a fan.
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Buy an Artline felt pen (this is an Australian brand pen with a steel pocket clip - see here http://www.pelikanartline.com.au/index.php?option=com_content_ex&view=category&layout=multi-view&id=69&Itemid=154 )and remove the steel clip from the lid. Print out, clear all holes and guides and install pen clip as shown. Install onto servo motor, and ensure the clip clears the gear. Reinstall onto printer, and extrude! You may need to adjust the size of the outlet guide hole if your spool curls too much (only open it up a little). This is a prototype design, but has been tested to work with some pretty bad filament! See the thread for more info: http://www.pp3dp.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=3&p=5646&sid=6f128c7472db717e051d901921f69eeb#p5646

comments.text: I think this is exactly what I need! My Afinia (an Up! release to the USA) has been clogging because it can't push the filament through because the plastic of the extruder is stretched and can't provide enough tension against the gear. This is a life saver! At least, I hope it is, and I'll get this printed up as soon as possible to get this thing back on the road. I got printing to do :D

print_settings.Notes:: Depends on the strength required how much infill and shells - be conscious of where the weaknesses might be due to the Z-layering and see if it is fit for purpose. Putting the X-Y printed bend under stress should give greatest strength.

description.text:
Used to join 25.4 mm / 1 inch square extruded aluminium together in various ways to make frames (generally sold in standard lengths in hardware stores or metal suppliers - e.g. known as Qubelok or Connect-IT in Australia). These connectors are designed to be printed flat without supports to improve printing times and avoid clean-up for rafts - so they aren't perfectly "cubic" as a result (to avoid overhang).

The use of aluminium extrusion square tubing allows for larger frames to be created - test out various degrees of in-fill or shells to see if it is strong enough (as with any 3D printed part that needs to take load).

Unlike the limited options for commercial joining pieces - by creating a 3D printed version (aka "Joinerers") there are a wide range of additional pieces and you can do funny angles if you need, hence the name "Joinerers" - for all those weird joinering needs!
All the standard things like 90 degree connectors (elbow, Tee, Cross, corner and intersection type connectors) as well as 45 degree, 30/60 degree, end caps (with and without the lip that some variations of the extrusion have) - if special angles are required get into sketchup and edit things to suit and then export to .stl (let me know of any additions or improvement and I can add to the next release!). Would suggest running through a "fix model" just to be sure as sketchup sometimes gets a bit imprecise with shapes.

To lock it all down once you have your frames built - some self tapping metal screws can do the trick - or update the shape to have longer/tighter fitting connectors. Feedback welcome! Also means you can have your choice of colours for your frame connectors.

Also intended to expand to allow joining of different shapes to this standard 25.4mm square tubing - e.g. 20mm square or round piping etc. Would like to build up an open source general set of connectors - would be a good way to allow for making use of whatever extrusions, piping or straight material there is around to make whatever is needed.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Depends on the strength required how much infill and shells - be conscious of where the weaknesses might be due to the Z-layering and see if it is fit for purpose. Putting the X-Y printed bend under stress should give greatest strength.

Tried a bunch of prototypes to get the sizing right and then created many variations. Used sketchup even though it gets a bit painful at times making proper 3d shapes for printing so that anyone could download and edit the source files using a free tool.
Getting the 6 way connector to be flat-printable took a bit of trial and error getting some sort of shape that would work as a raft-less/supportless shape.

comments.author: nathanking75

comments.text: Next version update:
comments.author: Nath

comments.text:
Next version I will update all the "cube" bits to have appropriate holes so that you can increase the strength by hammering in an insert piece. That will be a bit of a big refactoring as it's not a simple update. But if anyone is having trouble with the Z-axis bits failing - that's my solution for now. On my makerbot replicator 2 I aimed for a 0.1-0.2 gap in the insert shape and it will fit very snugly.
For this idea to work it needs to be tight or else you'll still have it fail as it can't share the load with the insert until things have flexed. The idea could also be that you could print the inserts with far greater shells/infill and they're quite quick to print in comparison as they're just a simple boxy shape.
comments.author: Nath

comments.text: I did create some higher strength ones - they're a bit of a work in progress - will refine for later release. For now: they are in the sketchup file if anyone wants them.

author: juntti99

title: Frame Intake Grill - 2013+ Triumph Street Triple

description.text:
Continuing my escapades modding my 2016 Triumph Street Triple, I converted the bug eyes to a single LED projector headlight, using the Motodemic Low kit.
I live in a highly wooded area so I decided that I'd prefer a grill to cover the intake inlet left gaping open at the front frame, which becomes exposed once you remove the stock headlight fixture.

It is a somewhat rushed design that I designed and printed while performing the conversion, but I was surprised that it fits into place as well as it does. It should be quite durable and able to withstand some engine heat due to the thickness and location.

Just pop it in after you are all done with your headlight conversion. Wiring hole on the clutch-side. Easy peezy!

A remix from an own remix - why that?

  • This is rather a quick hack, with mediocre code quality, rather than a "remix", consider it an early access version.
  • The usefulness of this item is limited, as it is used in conjunction with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1792366 - as it's sort of specialised, I didn't want to modify the template.

I slapped on rod mounting brackets, added basements to the holder, and added the rod clamps, and pins to tentatively hold the parts together.

Purpose of this thing: rest the filament spool holder on the two rods which join the Z top brackets, above the print head, where it is positioned such that filement is fed straight into extruder, no force or lots of pulling required.
These holders won't fit on a printer without those horizontal rods.
Two parts sets are needed for one holder.

To improve: square footprint studs for rod clamps, print studs laid out horizontally instead of as towering cylinders, which should make them stronger while easy print. Or use glue, screws, whatever.

Problems, improvements

Rather than add-on rod clamps, integrating those into the holder foot, while keeping ease of printing in mind, should be carried out, thereby eliminating the bolts for attaching rod clamps. The padlike feet would then disappear.

title: Filament Roller IR Sensor Version 1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Addendum (2017/01/23):
A Kickstarter campaign for this product is live:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/522476987/filament-roller
Make a donation and receive a finished Filament Roller. Thanks for your support~

Addendum (2016/11/13):
If you have a printer that can print 12x16 or larger, please visit version 2 of this thing at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1888159. Thanks!

Addendum (2016/11/27):
If you want an inline roller that you can position closer to your extruder separate from your spool, please visit version 3 of this thing at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1904929. Thanks!

Are you tired of nozzle clogs? Jamming? Filament grinding? Motor stalling? Tired of babysitting your printer, making sure it doesn't stop feeding filament?

This prototype Filament Roller can detect direction and speed of the filament spool using zero-friction optical IR sensors. If the spool rolls too slowly or stops, the board emits an alarm. This early-alert prevents your from losing your print, and gives you a chance to pause your print before it's too late.

Or, without the board, you can use it like a regular low-friction filament roller.

Required parts:
608 ball bearings (4 ea)
M3 x 12 mm screws (22 ea)
M3 x 18 mm screws (2 ea)
M3 nuts (24 ea)
M5 x 30 mm screws (4 ea)
M5 washers (4 ea)
M5 nuts (4 ea)

Optional parts:
Filament Roller control board (1 ea)
Small rubber bands (~16 ea)
Large rubber bands (4 ea)

Required printed parts:
Base part 1 (2 ea)
Base part 2 (2 ea)
Basic pylon (3 ea)
Pcb pylon (1 ea)
Pcb pylon foot (1 ea)
Roller (any slot# combo) (4 ea)
Tensioner (1 ea)

Addendum:
I hope to start a Kickstarter campaign to get the board manufactured. I will update this page with more details as they occur.

For more information on this project, check out: http://www.filamentroller.com/
For information on how this device works, check out: http://www.filamentroller.com/how-it-works/
A limited number of samples are available for purchase: https://www.etsy.com/listing/469008294/filament-roller-with-optical-sensor-and?ref=shop_home_active_1

Printer:

NoNameMadeInChina_i3Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm Z

Infill:

20-25%

Notes:

You know what works best for you ;-)

Post-Printing

Assembly instructions:
Assemble the base using 12mm M3 screws and nuts. To assemble the base, you will need 4 prints of the base. You will need 4 prints of the connectors. Use the connectors to attach the base pieces together. If you are using a PCB, use a half-connector on that side.

When choosing which rollers to print, consider how fast you operate your printer. If you use 3mm filament or print 20mm/s or slower, I recommend the 40-slot roller. If you print 1.75mm and very fast (60mm/s or higher), I recommend printing a 20-slot roller. A 40 slot roller has the highest resolution (40 slots x 4 edges per slot = 160 edges per revolution => 2.25 degrees per edge). It will product many sensor edges over a short period of distance or time.

Paint the rollers so that they are able to block IR light (1 mm ABS does not block IR). I use gold spray paint, but I think just about any kind of paint will block IR light. After painting the rollers, insert the bearings into the already-painted rollers using steady pressure. If you already inserted the rollers before painting the roller, you can use masking tape over the roller and paint it that way.

Attach the roller assembly to the pylons using M5 screws. On the backside of each pylon, secure the screws using a washer and nut.

If you are using a Filament Roller PCB, print 1 PcbPylon, 1 PcbPylonFoot, and 1 PylonFooter. Attach the elements in the following order using a 16-18mm M3 screw:
PcbPylon - Filament Roller PCB - PcbPylonFoot - Base - PylonFooter. Insert M3 nuts into the PylonFooter and screw the assembly tightly to the base.

For the pylons not connected to a Filament Roller PCB, print 1 BasicPylon and 1 Pylon Footer. Attach the elements in the following order using a 12mm M3 screw: BasicPylon - Base - PylonFooter. Insert M3 nuts into the PylonFooter and screw the assembly tightly to the base.

Attach short rubbter bands to the rollers to add grip between the rollers and filament spool.

After setting the pylons in the correct width and length to securely hold your filament spool, insert the tensioner through the hub of the filament spool. Attach rubber bands between the tensioner and the M5 screws on the pylons. This will add light tension to smooth out the filament feeding and mitigate the "spring" effect of the filament during operation.

Design

I used OpenSCAD to design the printed parts for this project. The source files are uploaded as well.

A stand for a water jar so it can sit on top of an a sink. Adapted to fit the edge of the sink.

Printed in ABS

I printed this in three sections. The top plate as one and the feet's as on(two). The reason for this was to not use support and also to be able to adjust the feet's on site if needed.

I've been lino-printing for a while and every now and then I start a multiple-color project.
Registration has always been a pain in the *** even though I've found several methods and infos about that.

The one solution I found might be the best is Ternes Burton registration pins http://www.ternesburton.com/. This method is very easy (and of course ternes burton did not invent that): registration is about position and rotation and two pins are enough to get these points fine. But do I really need it to be stainless steel? definitely not

Briefly, this is the same principle but easy to DIY with a 3dprinter.
every item must be printed in couple, for each couple of "pin" you need several couples of "foil", each couple of "foils" is one print.

I followed a tutorial to find out what I really needed
http://www.black-prints.com/how-to-get-the-perfect-registration-with-ternes-burton-pins/
I'm sure it'll be clearer than any explenation I might ever write =D

some prints (with and without it) on https://www.instagram.com/a_raush/

Dock designed to cradle the nokia DT-900 qi inductive charger at an angle. I designed this specifically for my new Nexus 5 phone but it should work with most other cellphones. I originally created this because the nokia charger is cheaper than the Nexus Orb (if you know where to look ). I wanted the angle but wanted to solve the problem of phones sliding off. Has worked well on my desk the last few days, seems durable enough that it will last. Update: I have updated the parts to use slightly less plastic and be more home printer friendly with less overhangs. Additionally I added the base and outer shell as one part which should be easier to print on a home printer. If someone wants to try and show their results that would be appreciated :)
I need to spend some time to get my home printer back up and running.
Also Check out my horizontal dock version in the remix section. I plan to use it combined with a NFC tag at home on my night stand as an alarm clock.

Print both pieces. I used a dimensions printer, I haven't tried it on my rep rap yet so I cant give any recommendations on settings. The walls are thin so I would print solid. (thinking about it now it might be easier to print this as one piece on a reprap. If needed I can provide these parts for someone)  
Glue the base to the bottom.   
(optional) stick some rubber feet on the base for a really solid grip  
Add a big bag of something heavy inside.  
Set the Charger in the grove.  
Enjoy.

The small hole at the bottom should be used to encore the clip to the destination part of the tension,
The string should be passed through the teeth part from the broad side of the clip (not the handle part).
You pull the string out through the teeth by just pulling the string.

Thank you all for your help and support.

Star Trek Silhouette
Star Trek 3D
Game of Thrones
Bioshock Rapture/Columbia

author: otto71

title: Mitsubishi Delica L400 curtain replacement hook

description.text:
My first go at 3D design.
My Mitsubishi Delica L400 came with nice stock curtains. Unfortunately, quite a few hooks were broken and the curtain didn't quite sit well on the window. Since I needed them quick, I just quickly designed a replacement.
Thickness is 2mm (close to original) but you can easily adjust it by changing the scale in Z axis.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

75%

Notes:

I printed it in Advanced PLA, 0.2mm 75% infill and it worked well.
I will try printing it in PETG as this will provide better mechanical properties.
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360. I can share original design files if anyone is interested.

description.text:
I made this for the partner to keep her makeup in. You can stack a number together to add more storage and twist each layer to get access to lower levels or store taller items.

Check out this cool wall hanger for it designed by Kb3Inn
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1801939

Printer:

Wanhoa Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

This is designed to fit on a 200mm x 200mm standard RepRap print bed. You may need to be careful with the placement of any clips on the edges.

The stacking system is designed with a draft angle so it should be relatively tolerant to resizing.

I had to make a shim for my folgertech kossel carriage, as the carriage was offset from the pulleys.
It is 5mm thick.

description.text:
These hooks were designed to hang up all the garden tools in my shed. In my shed they hang from a section of shirting board that is screwed to the upright beams.

The hooks have countersunk holes in case you need to fix them in place. I haven't found the need and like the freedom to reconfigure my shed more easily.

I made about 15 of the various sizes and hand all sorts from them including a lawnmower. So far they have been in use for about 6 months and are still working 100%.

Printer:

Wanhoa Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.3mm

Infill:

80% less if you dont need the strength

Notes:

I used ABS.

One of my devices consumes C-Type batteries. I bought accums of C size, but I did not want to buy a charger as I had a good AA bateries charger.

So I made a cradle for C-size batteries and an AA-size adapter. Push batteries to the cradle, adapters to the charger and you can charge C-type batteries

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Graber i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer

Infill:

30%

Glue 'spring' parts to the cradle at the minus side. These springs should help keeping a good contact between contact pads and battery

As a connector pads I used small pieces of a metal can. First solder wires to metal pads, then glue pads to the plastic. See soldering scheme on the photo.

comments.text: Thanks for the design! I have the exact same charger and was looking for a suitable adapter for my 4 rechargeable D-size cells. I'm going to print the AA charging adapters to start with and cobble up something for the D cells. I really should learn to draw..

title: Compartment Storage Box cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a compartment storage box for my screw assortment. So I designed this box with different sized compartments. I added tappets with corresponding recess to make the box stackable. As all the parts have pegs, the whole design just relies on press-fitting – no screws, no glue.

My build was done from a sheet of 4 mm high density fiber using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft. I used material from the back plane of a closet I reclaimed from the trash. The surface is coated with shiny yellow, which looks really nice.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs. Consider a donation if you like the build.

You can find another version with lid here.

The stl was uploaded just for a three dimensional display here on Thingiverse. If you want to print this – assuming you printer has a bed larger then 328 mm x 138 mm – you should extrude the dxf to the width of 4.15 mm.

comments.text: I am using a rather small end mill. The HDF demands for a single flute and my smallest has 2 mm diameter resulting in an one millimeter corder radius. I actually did without overcuts/dogbones. When press-fit this works well. You could use a small file if in doubt.

author: ZenziWerken

description.text:
A super lightweight stool with a 3D printed structure and carbon-fiber shell.  
The shape of the Gaudi Stool was created in the same way that Spanish Art Noveau architect Antoni Gaudi designed the structure of his churches, by making a model of hanging chains, so letting gravity determine the strongest and most logical shape for withstanding forces.  
Carbon-fiber and 3D printing were used to be able to apply Gaudi's methods in lightweight furniture.  
When a chain hangs in between two supports, it will follow a line defined by gravity. This is the catenary. When this line is reversed, a strong form for taking compressive forces emerges.

Materials and techniques:
The stool consists of a shell made out of carbon-fiber, and a substructure which was made by 3D-printing . The product weights exactly 1KG. There is a .stl file that you could use for printing. Note that the stool was designed to print using Selective Laser Sintering machines. You might want to tweak the file to make it suitable for other machines. I also included the orginal .3dm files. You can use those if you want to create derivative versions.
You'll notice there is a hollow sleeve in one of the legs. I used that to fit in a carbon-fiber insert that created a stronger connection between the carbon-fiber shell and the printed structure. It also adds to the strenght of the stool.
Through the layers in the model you can follow the different steps I took to get from lines to solids. For an elaborate instruction manual check: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Nr6gTMHCRU-gY8mjmFuCyFk_zjXIkMQrwYX1t4X9O0w/edit?usp=sharing

comments.text: For this effect to work correctly you should've put weights on the ropes, on the places where you expect to be a force from a person sitting on the stool. In the setup you used, the stool wil be strongest when it carries only itself. It will not be the strongest form when someone sits on it. The shape the ropes will take when the exact pattern of weights that will push on the stool are hung on them, will be the strongest shape for this stool.

title: PS4 control pad and headset mount. (can be attached with screws or zip ties)

description.text:
First off let me say that any donations for this design are greatly appreciated, thank you very much in advance!

This item is a mount for the playstation 4 control pad and a headset.

I have designed the mount so that you can either screw it to a wall or alternatively there is two hollows in the back of the mount which you can thread a zip tie (tie wrap) through to fix it to unusual backings. If you look through the pictures of the mount you will see an example of an unusual backing that I have attached it to, it is the post of my computer desk but it works an absolute treat.

The beauty with the playstation 4 controller holder is that it sits around the sticks of your analogue sticks perfectly so it is able to hold on to your control pad really well and any daily bumps it may get it should hold up against them and keep hold of your control pad really well.

The attached files are as follows:

Ps4_controller_and_headset_mount.123dx - This is the saved file from 123D design.

Playstation_4_headset_and_controller_mount.stl - This is the 3d model file produced by 123D design, you can open this with any slicing program to create your own sliced files.

ps4 headset and controller print gcode.gcode - This is your actual printing file, I have modified the supports using Simplify3D which are in the holes for your tie wraps. This is the exact Gcode I have used to print my Headset and control pad holder which has come out perfectly!

The settings I used to print my Headset and control pad mount are as follows:

Layer height - 0.25 mm
First layer height -0.32
Infill percentage - 15%
Infill pattern - Fast honeycomb
Support material overhang threshold - 50 degrees.
Support material pattern - Pillars
Extruder Temperature - 195 degrees (I have used PLA so modify these settings if using ABS or another material.)
Bed temperature - 0 degrees (I have used PLA so modify these settings if using ABS or another material.)

The slicing program I used was Simplify3D it may be slightly expensive but I absolutely swear by it, the support material it puts on comes off so easily. What would take me half an hour to clean up now takes me literally seconds, If you have a little bit of spare cash available I couldn't recommend it enough!

If you have absolutely any questions please feel free to message me and I will get back to you as soon as possible!

Happy printing!

title: Timing Belt Y MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

description.text:
This is for the Simple V2 w/o String tension ordered BEFORE 10/23/2013.
For models WITH string tension see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220484
The motor mount and tie bar are identical on both MXL designs. Having difficulty keeping consistent traction with the string drive on my Simple Y axis, I set out to design a more positive drive.
Design parameters were:
  • Timing belt drive
  • "Bolt on" solution, no modification of machine required
  • Ability to revert back to string drive if necessary
    • This has been running almost non-stop for over a week now without any issues, so it is time to share with the group. Enjoy. As always comments, concerns, and suggestions for improvements are not only welcome but encouraged. Update 1: Be careful not to over tighten the belt. In the gallery is a picture of my "quick fix" after getting a little wrench happy. I will draw up a little link bar that can be installed outside the drive gear to tie the bearings together very soon. Screws shown are M3 x 22mm. Update 2: I have added a couple files:
  • "Bearing Tie Bar" to allow for higher belt tension without deflecting bearings out of alignment. It has been designed for M3x22 screws, but M3x20 should work as long as you don't have too much debris in the hex nut socket.
    • "Motor Plate Option A" to completely remove the captive nut and allow for more strength of the bearing supports. There is no axial load on the bolts so there should be no problems with simply threading into the printed part.
    • Updated drawing to show link bar.

Notes:
  • The assembly of the timing belt pulley and bearings is close, but possible.
  • The bearings must be centered on the pulley
  • I had to lightly sand the upper edge of the wooden slot so the set-screw on the timing belt pulley would not rub.
  • The pulley sits on the end of the motor shaft. Less than ideal, but I haven't had any issues thus far.
  • 5mm drill bit used was from McMaster Carr 28255A39

comments.text: Hey guys, bit of a printr modding noob. I just got the XL upgrade and gt2 belts kit. I printed the parts and they all work with the screws and that stuf but the spot for the belt isnt wide enough (5mm vs belt of 7mm?) help? I dont want to mess with the files.
comments.author: Xaalman

comments.text:
If you have GT2 belts and pulleys you should use the GT2 upgrade: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194586http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
"MXL" or "GT2" are a type of belt with a specific tooth shape. They are not interchangeable. The GT2 is the most used belt form in these type printers. I made these MXL upgrades early in my adventure into 3d printing and simply used what I could buy thru McMaster Carr. Since then I have upgraded to the GT2 belts, and would recommend you do the same.
comments.author: Xaalman

comments.text: lawrence, I am hoping you can help me with a problem I am having. My print keep coming out shifted in the Y-axis. I have set all my speeds to a maximum of 50mm/s in both the firmware and slic3r, lowered the jerk settings, but I am still unable to fix this problem
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: Since you are posting this here, can I assume you have already installed the MXL timing belt modification and are still having trouble?  If so, have you adjusted your motor current?  Listen to the motor during a print and see if you hear the motor stall briefly.
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: I did, I never noticed a stalling sound. I guess it will have to wait. I was going to reprint all the parts again after re-calibrating my stock printer. Ran into other problems, the heating element failed during my last print.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: If motors are skipping steps:
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: If you are still shifting I can think of a few things:
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: I finally have this thing back up and running, but running a stock configuration with a slight modification. I am running my fishing line directly over the motor shaft. I am going to reprint all the upgrades, use a higher infill, slow the print down, and retry the upgrade. I will report back with my findings once everything is re-installed. Your last theory makes a bit of sense. The grub screw always seemed to keep getting loose no matter how tight I put it on there, next time I will try using some blue locktight. Thank you for the ideas, they will be a good path to start on.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: This is exactly what I need for my simple. I love the machine, but the string drive needs constant adjustment and has ruined many of my prints.
comments.author: 4volt

comments.text: I'd like to say I'm very pleased with your work I can tell you have spent a long time working on it. I'm sure many of us are thankful
comments.author: razrburn

comments.text: I am having the same issues on the Y-axis. Will have to try your spacer solution.
comments.author: razrburn

comments.text: If you are moving from the vinyl tube to this design, then you will have to increase the motor current slightly.  The timing belt pulley is a larger diameter than the vinyl tubing and therefore requires more torque which means more current.
comments.author: razrburn

comments.text: I'm sorry, but could you elaborate a bit on where you got the belt and the shaft adapter? The simple has been my first and only printer so I am at a bit of a loss where to get parts like these.
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: No need to apologize at all.  Sourcing parts is one of the most confusing parts of this whole adventure for me too. Getting over the learning curve of the printer itself, learning the lingo, and where to buy parts is a lot to absorb.  If you are in the US, then there are several online sources (links below for a few) for these type timing belts.  In my "Thing Files" you will find a PDF that gives you the McMaster Carr part numbers for the purchased hardware I used.  Not listed in the PDF is a 5mm drill bit (28255A39), that can also be purchased from McMaster if you need a source.
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: I have another concern, I might have destroyed my pulley.Here on thingiverse I found a customizable version.. I spent some time fine tuning the dimensions to get them as close as possible to the real part. Do you think this could work?
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text:
Could you clarify "destroyed my pulley"?
Many people have good luck with printing pulleys. You didn't give any details on what your found so I cannot offer any specific suggestions. Some of the problems I have heard are that if the motor gets hot, they soften and start to slip. I personally have not tried, and don't believe I will, simply because the accuracy of your print is VERY dependent on the quality of this part. For that reason I will stick with machined pulleys.
Don't get me wrong, in an emergency I would be among the first to print one out, tie wrap and superglue it to the shaft and hope for the best. At least until I am able to get a replacement.
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: Been so busy!, Thank you for the websites. I ordered everything listed in the PDF. Hopefully will have this installed by next week.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: I noticed the bearing 'pillars' are hollow in most of their height.  Perhaps it would be stronger to use longer screws and move the nut capture area closer to the base, giving more substance to the pillars?
comments.author: GeekDoc

comments.text:
GeekDoc,
As you found out, I left the clearance behind the nuts to make sure the bolts do not contact the wooden plate. On average, the first couple threads of a screw are malformed and shouldn't be trusted. Combine this with the nylon insert of the lock nut, moved the nuts to the position shown.
You do have a good point, and to increase the strength of the 'pillars' I have included a "Motor Plate Option A" file where you would simply thread into the printed part. There is little to no axial force on the screws, and unless your bearings seize up I wouldn't anticipate any issues.
I have also included a Tie bar which should work well with M3x22 bolts, however M3x20 may work as well depending on what you have on hand.
comments.author: GeekDoc

comments.text:
Printed this, and ordered parts. Thanks for great work and documentation!
I anxiously await your X-axis design.
comments.author: GeekDoc

comments.text: Thank you for the kind words.  Yesterday I managed to over tighten the belt and it pulled the bearings out of alignment.  See the pictures for my "quick fix."  Soon I will post a link to replace the tie wrap.
comments.author: GeekDoc

comments.text: I'm going to have to try this out. Gave you looked at converting the other axis to a belt as well?
comments.author: futile

comments.text: I do have a design on "paper", but I am not happy with it just yet.  I really want to stay with a "bolt on" design with as few part as possible. Also want to keep all printed parts printable on the build volume of the Simple.  In addition, my X axis has been working rock solid so I personally don't have any real need at the moment. I'll move it up the priority list if there is a need out there.
comments.author: futile

A 1:48th steam shovel. There are components to make a shovel, log loader, clamshell bucket or dragline. This is still a work in progress so there is more to come on this but its more than useable now.

Future work includes an earlier style chassis, a curved shovel arm, longer crane arm and a gas version. Several chassis are also in progress.

The made up model has a plasticard roof, not a printed on as that component came out looking too thick in comparison. All cables are fine electric wire taken from an old parrallel printer cable!

This will change as I add more components but for the moment, the basic building instructions are;

Main body
Print either body 2 or body 3, drill out the holes that the winches mount through as well as the hole at the top of the a frame and the mount for the arm. I use 2mm drill but it really depends on what you want to use for axles. Print out two winch drums and two of the drive units, the geared ones look better if you have the resolution. Push three short axles through the holes, the bottom two going through the winch drums to hold them in the place. Cut the top one flush but leave the bottom ones protruding where drive will go to help center the drive units. There are several types of drive if you wish to move them around for a particular prototype.

Mount the boiler in the back of the body (unless you want to go gas powered or anything)

Print the shovel arm and drill out the four holes, slide axles through the two on the end to form pulleys (if you have small plastic rod and washers and patience, these make excellent pulleys). Attach the shovel arm to the body with an axle.

Print the shovel out and use an axle to mount it to the shovel arm. This is an easly design that is fixed, later ones slid up and down at this point but that mod isn't done yet. You will need to use plasticard or something similar to make the door at the back of the shovel because I have just realised thats missing (sorry, I will fix that). Mount the shovel winch (which is a pulley) onto the end of the shovel. I would get the pose all glues as you want it before you touch the cables.

The chassis is printed in onto peice. I have enough patience print the track peices seperately and link together with pins. if you don't want to go insane, print out the long strip in once go. I bend it back and forth to get it to flex then wrap it around the wheels starting at the top and making some track sag between the wheels and idlers then wrap it around glue it underneath where you can't see the join.

I use a thick plastic axle to make the pivot between cab and chassis as this gives a smoother motion that anything I can print.

Once done, time for the fun bit, the cables!

You can do this in one of several ways but the cables are the way they are for a reason so unless you have a prototpe to follow;

The first cable starts under the end of the shovel arm, drops down, around the pulled on the shovel and back up over the end of the shovel, if you can get it down around the shovel pulley and back up again then it will look more realistic, this is the working part of the cable. Now take the remainder and wrap it around the lower drum, don't go back and forth over the main crane arm. The lower drum thus controls the bucket angle. The second cable goes back and forth between the top of the shovel arm and the axle on the top of the body, this lifts and lowers the arm, As many loops back and forth as you can (within reason) make it more realistic. Then drop this down and wrap around the upper drum. I use old printer serial cables for cables, I found thread was too thin.

Now put the roof on and tell me if I've missed any steps!

The clamshell and log loaders cable up pretty much the same way but check a prototype out for the subtle details!

I will do some diagrams for this when I get a chance but time is short at the moment, if you get stuck give me a shout!

description.text:
Note before printing: You will need K'Nex orange connector and bar of whatever length to make this stand work.

A basic stand for displaying K'Nex models. There is a slot for an orange KNex connector. Once you slide the connector into the slot, you can attach any of the bars by sliding into one of four holes and it will hold the bar in place. This may take some practice and messing around to get to work. The way it was designed causes the orange connector to not open as easily as it would normally. You can also attach the bar to the orange connector piece first and slide the unit in but it will be difficult since the clearances are tight to ensure the bar is as strong and rigid as possible. It can be done, and once done it is a solid stand. A video can be made if there are enough requests on how to setup this stand.

title: Arc Hammer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Arc Hammer was a titanic space faring construction facility constructed at Kuat Drive Yards and was classified as a dreadnaught After the destruction of the newest Imperial superweapon, the Death Star in 0 BBY, the Empire started to share General Rom Mohc's views, who considered that all soldiers should be given a chance to face each other in a one-on-one combat. Mohc eventually persuaded the Imperial officials to greenlight the Dark Trooper Project, which involved creating droid versions of Imperial stormtroopers. To this end, he was provided with the Arc Hammer.

In order to ensure secrecy of the project, the factory frequently made jumps to hyperspace, and only one ship, the Dark Lord of the Sith Darth Vader's Super Star Destroyer Executor, knew its exact position at any given time. The Dark Trooper project proceeded quickly, and by 0 ABY the first working prototypes were made. To demonstrate the power of the Dark Troopers, it was arranged to attack the Rebel Tak Base on the planet Talay. The demonstration was successful; only one Rebel ship managed to escape from the planet, although it was boarded by a Dark Trooper as well, who then killed all crew aboard. The Tak Base itself was destroyed with all hands. However, before its destruction, Admiral Toka managed to send a distress signal. After receiving the distress signal, the Rebel-allied mercenary Kyle Katarn was assigned to investigate the loss of Tak Base. While there, Kyle discovered a large gun, too cumbersome to be efficiently wielded by a regular stormtrooper.

Eventually, after investigating various secret Imperial factories and weapons scientists, he learned of the Dark Trooper Project, and infiltrated Arc Hammer via a cargo transfer. He later destroyed the ship by placing sequencer charges throughout certain exhaust ports within the ship.

This Model is from the MOD Awakening of the Rebellion by the Steiner Modding Group for Star Wars: Force of Corruption. I do not claim ownership or creative licence.

description.text:
Edit 2016.10.03: Added another 2 parts for audio. The PCB is the cheap one from ebay with an PAM8403 (22mm x 22mm dimension) with incredible 2 x 3000 mW ;-) The speaker dimensions are 28mm in diameter and a 3mm high cup.
//edit end;

This is a stand for a Raspberry and 4.3" LCD.
The LCD has the following dimensions:
121mm x 76mm x 3mm

I've modified the parts compared to the photos, because one USB and probably the network-ports are/could be blocked.

You need M4x20 bolts and nuts for the ribs and ~M2.5 bolts to mount the raspberry.

All 4 parts for the edges are different, because the raspberry with his mounting holes is not symmetrical. The ribs are both identically, because of this I've uploaded them only once.

All parts are aligned in "load, slice and print" positions. The one of you with the bigger printer could combine all parts on one plate.

title: Indiana Jones: Cross of Coronado
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"It belongs in a museum!" - Indy

I'm happy to share the Cross of Coronado from Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade. This package comes with everything but the Crucifix Jesus Figure; I got mine from 123D, just search for Crucifix christ. As I was building this prop, I realized that it gave much more realistic touch to the model when I separated the ornament arcs and glued them later on. This might take some extra time, but it's absolutly worth it.

This is how you work through

  1. Print the main cross parts and pray paint them. Be aware that you check the dimensions, I had to scale it down to 97% to get it in my printer.
  2. Paint the top cross with blue emaille color. Get some mother of pearl veneer and cut it to 3mm strips, then glue two layers on the cross. Mother of pearl is quite fragile and expensive, yet very convincing. It brings live to the cross!
  3. Print the hooks and shafts, spray paint them and glue the on the top cross. You may need to re-drill hook holes.
  4. Print the ornaments and spray paint them. It looks like a pain to attach all of these tiny stuff, but actually it's pretty straight forward. Be sure to pre-allign it first before glueing. Should fit just right.
  5. Print any Jesus Christ model you can find, make sure that it'll fit the cross. I attached a halo STL for him :-) UPDATE: I think you can use GILLESBOENISCH Design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1864977
  6. Get perls, or stones or whatever. Outer perls are 8mm in diameter, the big ones are 10mm.
  7. Glue perls and Jesus to the cross. Glue the bottom cross to the top cross. Get some nice brass chain an attach it to the hook.

Hope you like it and please share your makes. =)

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

No

0.1 - 0.2

20

Notes:

I printed the parts in various res., like 0.1mm for the ornaments up to 0.15 mm for the crosses. Other resolutions will probably work as well.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:166045

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=166045

Using the following options:

bracket_thickness = 3
pcb_width = 60.0
fan_hole_spacing = 71.50
bracket_length = 10
screw_diameter = 3.25
bracket_height = 35
fan_size = 40
cross_bracket = 5

This is a heated chocolate extruder based on the Moineau pump (progressive cavity pump) principle. 
It can be used to print objects from chocolate.

Print the parts. There are two driveshafts, for motors with 20 and 24 mm shafts, others can be produced from the .scad file. Also, there are two versions of the main body, one with "fixed2" in the name (the original) and the other, marked "fixed4", where a couple of minor manifold issues have been fixed with netfabb. These should otherwise be 100% identical and the netfabb-fixed one should slice and print more reliably, but I have not actually printed that one. I recommend 0.20mm layer height. 0.25 might work too, but more than that probably won't. Note: PLA is sort of food-safe, but ABS most likely isn't. Don't use ABS except when printing for purely decorative purposes. Drill a hole in the nozzle, 1.2 mm and 1.6 mm are good starting points. Cut a gasket for the nozzle flange, I used bicycle inner tube. Attach nozzle with M3 nuts and M3x10 bolts. From the other end, push the rotor all the way into the stator cavity, then fit the driveshaft and attach a NEMA17 stepper motor with the motor coupler piece fitted to the end of the motor shaft (requires flats on two sides), making sure that the coupling teeth fit together. The extruder should now be ready to be fitted to the printer - it bolts directly into the latest Prusa X carriage with the 40mm circular hole. The extruder also needs warm air - otherwise trying to get repeatable results or results at all is hopeless. The pipe opposite the funnel can be used to fit an air hose (I used a washing machine water outlet hose). The air circulates inside the heat shroud around the pump and inlet block and exits around the funnel. A shoe dryer supplies the warm air in my setup. The temperature should be just a little below 30C. The object to be printed can be sliced into GCODE pretty much the same as when printing with plastic, but the layer height should be larger to accommodate the larger nozzle, and the filament diameter has to be set much higher. In my setup, with E_STEPS_PER_MM set in the firmware to 1800 and with a 1.2 nozzle, I used 18mm as the filament diameter to print the Flying Spaghetti Monster seen in the pictures. (Layer height was 0.7mm). The effective filament diameter also depends on the nozzle size, since smaller nozzles cause more backflow in the pump (because with plastic parts, it won't seal properly). Also, set the infill density to 100% - chocolate really doesn't handle overhangs... Then it's time to melt some chocolate (I wrote a bit about it here: http://reprap.org/wiki/Chocolate_Extrusion but the main point is: don't exceed 33.8C), pour it into the extruder's supply funnel and see what happens.

comments.text: Did you print the Rotor and stator of the Pump with usual PLA or something special like a flexible filament? Also i tried to Print only the Pump element, but with just water it didn't work at all. Does it work better with less liquid thing or did i just do something wrong?
comments.author: obbm123

comments.text: oh i forgot to mention i used your other version, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15538 , but comment here because thats what i'm actually trying to achieve (the other version was just smaller to print and by the general function it seemed identically). I tried with water and by turning it by hand, but didn't pump at all (the rator got a little bit wet but thats it). I noticed that the rator is a little bit "wobbly", should i try printing it again with a smaller clearance? Or is it just (because of the printing or because of the pump system) not possible to pump something as liquid as water? But Emmets version (on which yours is based, right?) seems to work with water so i'm not sure if(what) i'm doing wrong...
comments.author: obbm123

comments.text: Emmett's version pumps a much larger volume per rotation so it can pump water even though there is some leakage between the stator and the rotor. I have only used hard materials for printing this one and if the rotor fits without unnecessary play, it will work for printing thicker materials such as chocolate. There will be a significant amount of backflow in the pump, but that can be handled by calibration.
comments.author: obbm123

comments.text:
Okay, thanks. In that case i'll print the rotor again with smaller tolerances and try again, with chocolate again.
But you also talk about the backflow, is drooling a big problem while printing with this Extruder or can you get it under control with small tolerances and changing the gcode for more retract?
comments.author: ttsalo

comments.text: I didn't notice drooling being a problem, the flow from the nozzle seemed to stop as soon as the pump stops.

comments.author: Ioan

comments.text: Hi Tomi. Wonderfull work! I want to ask you how quickly the chocolate is hardening? Did you considered using a cooler to help the layers hardening more quickly? Look at this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8114 . It is a vortex tube, works with compressed air at 5 bar. On one side it will output warm air, higher than room temp. and on the other side will output COOL AIR at may be -20 deg. C. Also you can find more reliable designs on the internet. Such vortex tubes are used in industry for spot cooling which is exactly what we want!
comments.author: Ioan

comments.text: I have been testing with no extra cooling and it hardens quite slowly. To build more interesting objects, it will need some sort of external cooling. I have been thinking of everything from peltier elements mounted under the build plate to blowing cooled air. This is an open area of research if anyone wants to have a go...
comments.author: Ioan

comments.text: Here is an example of how a small company was helped to quickly cool down chocolate molds: http://blog.exair.com/2011/11/01/refrigerated-air-from-compressed-air/http://blog.exair.com/2011/11/...
comments.author: ttsalo

comments.text: Chocolate needs to stay below 33, but if you wound the temperature up to 70 or 80, it could print polymorph!, just add a hopper arangement above the material feed and we're free of the problems of filament tolerance and quality, just pour in a bag of granuals and go.
comments.author: ericbrooke

comments.text: That stuff sounds interesting, but it looks like it won't flow on it's own? This extruder requires the material to flow down the supply funnel without external help. The pump itself can pump pretty much anything but the supply side works with just gravity here.
comments.author: ericbrooke

comments.text: That's a great idea! Did you consider using water to heat the chocolate? You could connect up two small pipes and then use an aquarium heater+pump to pump a properly controlled temperature of water around the extruder.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I did consider that, but since the chocolate comes in preheated and only needs to be held a couple of degrees above room temperature, the power of water heating isn't really needed. Air is simpler and tiny leaks don't matter (it may not be easy to make all the thin walls totally watertight).
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: what an excellent idea! my wife is also thrilled! :)
comments.author: zapman

comments.text: I ran the main extruder STL through netfabb and sure enough, that found a couple of degenerate faces. That fixed version can now be found under the name "choco_stepper_main_fixed4.stl". I'm leaving the original version with fixed2 in the name just in case.
comments.author: zapman

comments.text: I checked it out with the Slic3r 0.7.0 and yep, it did complain about not being manifold. I then exported a new STL with the newest OpenSCAD version but it still complains. I checked the output, newest OpenSDAD and newest Slic3r, layer by layer, and it looks totally correct. So I think it's safe to print even with the complaints. The newest STL should show up with "fixed3" in the filename.
comments.author: zapman

comments.text:
&
gt;Don't use ABS except when printing for purely decorative purposes.
comments.author: lars0

comments.text: ABS contains styrene which is made from benzene, which causes cancer and other nasty things. I would avoid using it with foodstuffs unless I had the data sheet for the specific brand I'm using and that had a food-safe certification for it. PLA is a better bet, it has an FDA approval as food safe.
comments.author: lars0

comments.text: I wouldn't bet that anything but "natural" PLA would be considered food safe, without seeing a certification for it.  While the PLA itself might be food safe, the additives and colorants used in it may not be.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Wish I could like this one a second time... Nicely done!  8-)
comments.author: pwc-phil

comments.text: I had to stare at the Thingiview for awhile before I understood: you actually direct the hot air through a jacket around the entire mechanism to keep it evenly warm.  Hat's off, that's a spectacular design.  As someone who has tempered chocolate by hand to make truffles, I understand how important keeping an accurate temperature is.  What this really needs is a PID temp control like the other extruders.
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: Yeah, I actually thought that chocolate was an easy material to work with before I tried this... proper temperature control is a must. I haven't fitted an actual sensor inside this (yet) and I'm not sure what would be a good location.
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: Ideally if you have temperature control on your hot air supply you should put the sensor as close to the nozzle as you can get it so you know what temperature you are putting down.  The closer you put it to the chocolate / air mixing chamber the less accurate it will be.  Just a thought, but have you thought about using an induction coil?  If it works at the low temps it might be less cumbersome and easier to monitor then using heated air.
comments.author: ttsalo

comments.text: My Melzi board had a meltdown so I swapped it out for a RAMPS board (which supports bed leveling).
comments.author: 3D_Creations_Lab

comments.text: So if I'm understanding, this addition makes bed leveling much easier? The probe tells you distance of the bed as you adjust?
comments.author: mredmon

comments.text: You can use it that way... use the probe to mechanically level the bed by measuring the distance at multiple spots.  But the point is to allow the probe to automatically measure the bed and compensate for the amount that it is unlevel in software dynamically as an object is printing.  It is still beneficial to have a fairly level bed but it's not as critical.
comments.author: donjakobo

comments.text:
could you upload your firmware , i cant get it to auto level properly with my ramps 1.4
or upload your configuration file
comments.author: mredmon
ccccc382

comments.text:
It seems you don't have the x and y offset from the extruder to the probe in your firmware.
Did you run the G32 command? Because if you did not, it will not autolevel.
if you feel the z axis screws moving when moving the extrude left or right, you will have auto leveling on.
comments.author: mredmon

comments.text: When I add in the correct x and y offsets, the G29/G32 commands do their 3 point measurement and then the printer seems to try and move to a position that is (x offset, y offset) more than the last probing location... which is outside my print bed.  This is with the latest release of Repetier (not the development version).

description.text: Got inspired by Elon's latest speech about his plans to go to Mars. Designed a model based on the presentation of his proposed Mars Transport Vehicle. Scaled it the best I could based upon the pictures and some specs in the presentation. Rocket has 3 parts...the Raptor engine array, the fuselage, and the personnel transport cone. Haven't printed this out yet but I think I have some tips. Print the Raptor array engines up and set the perimeter to 1, I designed the thickness of the engine cone to the width of a single extrusion. Print the fuselage upside down, I think it will build better with the fins and the inner engine stop ring. Because the actual rocket is extremely huge some the the smaller details when scaled down might be lost, like the grid fins, I don't know. For reference, the fuselage is 7" tall, was basing the scale on my ROBO's capabilities in regards to the Z axis. Still tweaking some of the details, and will probably do some more when I get to printing this...enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

"Beauty blooms even amid brutality."
-Qie Zi, The Art of Seej

Last week I came downstairs to find the elder Zhengspawn had gotten into my acrylics and was busily painting one of the myriad bloxen that lurk in the crevices of Casa de Zheng. The original was printed in clear PLA on my Printrbot Simple; I think this is a nice improvement. I created some relief on the surface of the geometry to match the paint job. Read all about the sculpting process here.

title: Bracket for Belted Extruder for 2020 profile
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bracket for my Belted Extruders V3

Usage:
Mounting on 2020 alu-extrusions or any other surface.

Please let me know you you have a different bracket in mind you would like to see.

BOM:

m3 10mm screws to attach Bracket to Extruder

Printer:

CrossBot My Version

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed using 0.4mm nozzle

  • 3 perimeters/borders
  • 20%infill - recommending 40+
  • 3 top and 3 bottom layers
  • Use whatever layerheight you want
  • I used PrimaSelect PLA, which I havn't learned to use quiet yet..

Please report back on your experience

As I made this by request and do not have any 2020 extrusions to test on, I am a bit unsure wheter the 2 screws attached to the bottom of the extruder can fit in there.

You can use a spacer or 3, if they are too close to your extrusions... or just don't use them.

The side screws to mount the extruder should be enough.

comments.text: Any chance of getting a remix of this that uses M5 screws to attach to the extrusion? Most people that use Misumi extrusions anyway, use M5 screws to attach things to the extrusions.
comments.author: redelman

comments.text: You can just put a 5mm drill through it. I guess you'd make it pretty solid in any case :)

comments.text: Which is what I ended up doing, but not everyone has a 5mm drill bit laying around. :)

description.text: Pokemon Eevee for a lasercutter

This is a quail egg cutter. You can't just crack open a quail egg like you can with a chicken egg. You have to cut the top off and pour out the contents. This cutter makes that possible.

It prints in three parts. Glue the frame together with super glue and slide in the cutting blade.

I printed mine at 100% infill.

I've made a video of this item in use and you can view it at https://youtu.be/0UO4l0bFPoA

**UPDATE - Finger hole now goes all the way through frame for easier use.

description.text: Topological cube. Measures 50 mm x 50 mm x 50 mm

A mount for Logitech C270 webcam with its stand taken off. Very likely to work with other similar Logitech cameras with same stand design. Hangs in front of Ultimaker and angle of the camera can be adjusted.

I attached the camera to the mount with two M3 8mm screws. You can also use a M2.5*20mm bolt and a M2.5 nut. Mount and balancer can be joined by glueing them together. Or with acetone if ABS is used for printing.

This is an improved, more simple design over the original Ultimaker 2 webcam mount.

comments.text: I used a M2.5*20mm and a nut. Worked like a charm.

description.text:
I loved Bizzar's optimized remix of this, but found he left some room on the table to reduce print time and plastic use, so I removed the nonfunctional extended curved area near the mounting screw.

This change allows me to fit 7x onto a 152x154 mm build platform, and I think it is now even more aesthetically pleasing :)

Simplify 3D usage notes (FiveAngle / Bizzar / Mostlighting):

  • Build time (minutes): 27 / 28 / 31
  • Fillament used (mm): 3526.0 / 3586.3 / 3866.2
  • Plastic weight (g): 10.6 / 10.78 / 11.62
  • Cost ($USD): 0.267 / 0.272 / 0.304

description.text: Print solid at low resolution. Be very careful removing the raft. Clean up the edges before attempting to turn. It may take some force on the first few turns, but then it should spin freely. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/0SOmu8fwGk2

The camera mount replaces the one that comes with the QX 90. It has guides that help the camera stay put on the base and it has support that protects the antenna.

The weight is less than 1 gram (since it does not register on my scale).

I have included the SolidWorks design file if you wish to mod.

I printed this in ABS which is a little more flexible than PLA

I added a 20 degree mount variant due to requests. I havent actually used the the 20 degree mount, but did print it and it looks totally viable. YMMV.

remixed_from.title: Proton Pack Thrower Hand Grip Parametric(ish)

title: Ghostbusters Particle Thrower Proton Gun Neutrino Wand Grip

description.text:
I decided to make a more screen accurate version of this grip to match the ones seen here:

http://i.imgur.com/vkj2zZW.jpg

and on this build:

http://ironmanofmaine.weebly.com/stark-industries-ghostbuster-tech/3d-printed-proton-pack

It seems most people were buying a resin cast or even a printed grip from another site and I couldn't find any other model with a close enough shape so I remixed tgoacher's grip, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:574866 , using tinkercad and made this.

It should fit perfectly on a standard 1" PVC pipe from Home Depot. This model will print fine on a raft with no support

To get that "smooth" resin look after printing, fill the fine grooves with Bondo Glazing and Spot putty (or similar product), allow to dry, sand, prime, and paint.
